docs.lead_paragraph: Faced with pressure from lawmakers and editors of medical journals, four trade groups representing the world's biggest drug makers said yesterday that their members planned to release more data about clinical drug trials. In a joint statement, the groups said their member companies had committed themselves to disclose more information about drug studies, both when the studies are started and when results are released. The groups included the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Association in Washington and organizations in Europe and Japan.

headline.main: Drug Industry Plans Release Of More Data About Studies

docs.abstract: Four trade groups representing world's largest drug makers, including Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers Association in Washington and organizations in Europe and Japan, say their members plan to release more data about clinical drug trials; plans, which are voluntary, appear to reflect effort by drug industry to defuse controversy over clinical trials; American Medical Association says it still intends to push for federal law mandating trial disclosure (M)
docs.snippet: Faced with pressure from lawmakers and editors of medical journals, four trade groups representing the world's biggest drug makers said yesterday that their members planned to release more data about clinical drug trials.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: PHARMACEUTICAL RESEARCH AND MANUFACTURERS OF AMERICA

byline.original: By BARRY MEIER; Heather Timmons contributed reporting from London for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Maclyn McCarty, the last surviving member of a Manhattan scientific team that overturned medical dogma in the 1940's and became the first to demonstratethat genes were made of DNA, died on Sunday. He was 93 and lived in New York. His death was announced by Rockefeller University, where he worked for more than 60 years.

headline.main: Maclyn McCarty Dies at 93; Pioneer in DNA Research

docs.abstract: Dr Maclyn McCarty, last surviving member of Manhattan scientific team that was first to show genes were made of DNA, dies at age of 93; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. Maclyn McCarty was the last surviving member of a Manhattan scientific team that demonstrated that genes were made of DNA.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Maire Connolly learned about the tsunami on Dec. 26, she was torn: should she leave her family in Ireland to return to the World Health Organization in Geneva, where she leads the team that responds to health problems after natural disasters? Or should she stay with her parents, whom she rarely sees because of her work? Technology made the decision easier. Dr. Connolly stayed in Ireland and spoke by telephone most of each day with her deputy, Dr. Michelle Gayer, in Geneva.

headline.main: From a Far Continent, Victims' Needs Beckon. But So Does Her Family.

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Maire Connolly, head of World Health Organization team that responds to health problems after natural disasters, about her work and impact of recent deadly tsunami in Indian Ocean; Connolly, who is home with her family in Ireland for holidays, describes balance between very important global work and family life; specific challenges to providing aid for devastated region discussed; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The dilemma faced by one doctor after the disasters in Asia: stay with her family or lend her expertise.

keywords.name: glocations
keywords.value: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal advisory panel, working closely with the Bush administration, announced a list of 146 types of prescription drugs on Monday that should be covered under Medicare's new drug benefit. The panel, the United States Pharmacopeia, a venerable organization that sets standards for the pharmaceutical industry, said prescription drug plans should offer beneficiaries at least two drugs of each type. Insurers that follow the recommendations will be presumed to meet one of the major criteria in the new Medicare law.

headline.main: Advisory Panel Lists Drugs It Wants New Law to Cover

docs.abstract: Federal advisory panel working closely with Bush administration announces list of 146 types of prescription drugs that should be covered under Medicare's new drug benefit; insurers that follow its recommendations will be presumed to meet one of major criteria in new Medicare law; some patient advocates say guidelines do not guarantee coverage for new costly effective drugs that might be needed to treat certain conditions; guidelines appear to come down in favor of insurers, who seek to limit number and types of drugs, more than drug companies, that want as many drugs as possible on list (M)
docs.snippet: A federal panel, working closely with the Bush administration, announced a list of 146 types of prescription drugs that should be covered under Medicare's new drug benefit.

docs.lead_paragraph: It lasted only for a few hours, but the situation that unfolded in an isolated elementary school in the town of Sagaman on Sri Lanka's devastated east coast on Friday is just what public health workers fear. After a false warning from the Indian government of new tsunamis in the Indian Ocean on Thursday, hundreds of victims of last Sunday's huge waves abandoned government refugee camps near the shore and fled to Sagaman in a panic. Fleeing three miles inland on foot and in tractors, more than 150 men, women and children commandeered a school building without running water, flush toilets or food.

headline.main: Aid Workers Tackle Panic And Rumors

docs.snippet: After a false warning of new tsunamis, hundreds of victims of last Sunday's huge waves abandoned government refugee camps near the shore.

byline.original: By IAN FISHER and DAVID ROHDE; Ian Fisher reported from Colombo, Sri Lanka, for this article, and David Rohde from Sagaman, Sri Lanka

docs.lead_paragraph: Employer health plans across the country are forcing millions of consumers to change their drug-buying habits. And one side effect could be the decline of the neighborhood drugstore. Instead of picking up their medicines at a local pharmacy, growing numbers of consumers will be required -- starting this month when new health plans take effect -- to buy dozens of widely used drugs, like insulin for diabetes or Lipitor to lower cholesterol, by mail order.

headline.main: Drugstores Fret as Insurers Demand Pills by Mail

docs.abstract: Employer health plans across country are forcing millions of consumers to change their drug-buying habits; one side effect could be decline of neighborhood drugstore; growing numbers of consumers, starting in Jan when new health plans take effect, will be required to buy dozens of drugs by mail order; employers and companies that manage prescription drug insurance coverage favor mail-order pharmacies because they can get lucrative rebates and deep discounts from drug makers when they buy in volume; savings, which amount to hundreds of millions of dollars a year, can then be shared with employers and health plans; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Many people will soon be required to receive their drugs by mail order so their employers can get lucrative rebates and deep discounts.

docs.lead_paragraph: The vanguard of a global relief effort converged on the tsunami-ravaged coasts of Indonesia and other stricken nations yesterday as millions of survivors grew increasingly desperate and the death toll soared past 140,000 from a disaster that cast a shroud over the world's New Year celebrations. While a trickle of aid reached a handful of devastated communities in the worst-hit areas of northern Sumatra and an airlift began landing tons of food, medicine and other supplies at regional airfields where it was piling up, the relief operation confronted a lack of trucks and fuel, washed-out roads and bridges, power failures and other problems, and most of the aid was not getting through to those who needed it.

headline.main: Relief Delivery Lags as Deaths Pass 140,000

docs.abstract: Global relief effort converges on tsunami-ravaged coasts of Indonesia and other stricken nations as millions of survivors grow increasingly desperate and death toll soars past 140,000; relief operation confronts many problems, and most of aid is not getting through to those who need it; trickle of aid reaches handful of devastated communities in northern Sumatra; 10 helicopter airdrops and truckloads of supplies finally reach remote Meulaboh where 7,000 are confirmed dead and officials say third of population of 120,000 may have perished; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The vanguard of a relief effort converged on the stricken nations as millions of survivors grew increasingly desperate.
